data.text:
York University Heights is part of the University of Toronto surrounded by York University. York University Heights is a densely populated neighbourhood that consists of a number of distinct areas. It is home to students at York University, and it is also a major shopping destination. The area has a number of unique characteristics that make it a great place to live. This article will highlight some of the most important things you need to know about living in York University Heights.

Man with a Wrench loves University Heights Toronto

One of the most appealing aspects of living in York University Heights is the fact that it is surrounded by York University. The proximity of all this, coupled with the fact that you are only a short drive from Toronto, makes York University Heights a great place to call home.

York University Heights Toronto History

The area of York University Heights was once part of the rolling acres of farmland that covered much of the core of present-day Toronto. The University of Toronto was established in 1827, and it was the first university in Canada. The area that is now York University Heights was originally called York University, in honour of the university. York University Heights is where the university is located today.

When was York University Heights Toronto constructed?

The Village at York University is a new-home development spearheaded by York University. It features condominiums, townhouses, semi-detached and detached homes. The first residents moved into the first phase in 2005 when the first 550 homes were built. After that a second phase, which started construction in 2007, added about 300 more homes but includes no new townhouses.

Toronto is naturally rich in natural resources, and there was potential for agriculture. In the late 1800s, a man by the name of Henry Dunant came to the area, and he began to farm. He was also a mechanical engineer by trade, and he conceived the idea of a self-contained city where he could create jobs for the unemployed.

In 1904, he purchased the site and began to build the city. The city was planned with a residential area at the front, with a commercial core to the rear. The core of the city was the land that is now York University Heights.

What are the benefits of living in York University Heights Toronto?

One of the biggest benefits of living in York University Heights is the proximity to the University of Toronto. There are very few residential areas that are as close to a school campus as this. This is great for students and parents, as you will be able to walk or bike to class virtually every day. You’ll find that there are a lot of events and activities planned for students each year, and there are always new ones coming up.

Another big benefit is that it is very easy to get to work or school. You’re only a short drive from the subway, and you’re only a short drive from the highway if you want to drive. Also, if you’re a working parent, you’re in great hands with the nice and helpful staff at the York University Parent Centre.

The challenges of living in York University Heights Toronto

As with most things in life, living in York University Heights is not without its challenges. The most significant one is maintenance. A major challenge that you will have to deal with is parking. York University has a lot of students, so finding a place to park can be difficult. On top of that, some of the lots are small, and you might not be able to park in the correct area during rush hour. As with everything, though, with a little effort and perseverance, you can overcome these challenges.

Common Electrical Issues for houses in The Village at York University Toronto

The electrical issues that you will face in your house in York University Heights, especially if you’re a first time homeowner, are actually quite minor compared to the issues that other homeowners will face.

Here are some of the most common electrical issues you will run into in your house in York University Heights:

Wiring in walls

Voltage switches

Electrical outlets

Wiring in ceilings

Fuses

Lighting in ceilings

Wiring in walls

The wiring in your walls is actually quite simple. Your electrical outlets will be connections for devices such as a computer, TV, and other home appliances. Your electrical switches will be for controlling the devices such as on/off switches for lights and outlets for charging devices.

Common Plumbing issues for houses at York University Heights Toronto

The plumbing issues in York University Heights, particularly if you are a first time homeowner, are actually quite minor compared to the issues that other homeowners will face.

Here are some of the common plumbing issues you will run into in your house in York University Heights:

Showers and toilets don’t work

Drains are clogged

Broken pipes

Showers and toilets don’t work

This one is pretty self-explanatory. Your shower and/or toilets don’t work, and it’s pretty common for this to be a result of a clogged drain. Let our team take a look at your slow flow and clogged drains to see what is causing it and what needs to be done to fix it.

Common HVAC Issue after 20-25 years for Homes in York University Heights, Toronto

Since most of the neighborhoods in York University Heights were built around 2005-2007 it is time for some inspections and updates. If you are living in this area then your older AC unit could be having problems because of wear and tear, reduced efficiency, refrigerant leaks, improperly working fans, or anything else that could be causing it to malfunction.

Generally in colder climates, residents may not be as wear and tear on their HVAC systems. Even though they’re built to withstand this usage, it usually lasts around 15-25 years in a temperate climate.

Your HVAC systems should be checked by a professional every 6 months. This means that if you have a standard central AC or heat pump system, each of these units should be maintained, each year. If you have a heat pump system that you use year-round, then your service will need to be scheduled once every 6 months!
